Feminist theology has had a significant impact on the portrayal of Mary Magdalene in popular culture. Prior to feminist theology, Mary Magdalene was often depicted as a sinful woman who had been saved by Jesus, with her main role being one of repentance and conversion. However, feminist theologians have challenged this portrayal and worked to recover Mary Magdalene's role as a leader and witness in the early Christian community.

This recovery has led to a shift in how Mary Magdalene is portrayed in popular culture. Rather than being seen solely as a penitent sinner, Mary Magdalene is now often portrayed as a powerful and influential figure. This can be seen in films such as "The Passion of the Christ" and "Mary Magdalene," as well as in books and other media.

Additionally, feminist theology has highlighted the gendered nature of Mary Magdalene's portrayal, noting that her association with sin and sexuality may have been influenced by patriarchal attitudes towards women. This too has influenced how Mary Magdalene is represented in popular culture, with many depictions now emphasizing her strength and agency rather than her supposed sinful nature.

Overall, the impact of feminist theology on the portrayal of Mary Magdalene in popular culture has been significant, helping to shift our understanding of her from one of a marginal figure to that of a powerful and influential leader in the early Christian community.
